facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 5 of 1971 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated December 18, 21, 1970 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 1583 of 1970.

facts.text: The Bombay High Court issued a writ of quo warranto declaring that respondent No. 3 Dr. Balkrishna Pandurang Apte is not entitled to act as the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Poona pursuant to the election held on 9 May, 1970 and restraining him from acting as the Vice-Chancellor.

facts.text: V. Pataskar, the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Poona died on 21 February, 1970.

facts.text: The Governor of Bombay, who is the Chancellor of the University, nominated Maha Mahopadhyaya Datto Vaman Potdar to act as the Vice-Chancellor until another Vice-Chancellor was elected under sub-section (1) of section 11 of the Poona University Act, 1948.

facts.text: The Executive Council recommended a panel of three persons: Dr. Balkrishna Pandurang Apte, Principal Narayan Ramchandra Kulkarni and Principal Narhar Govind Suru for election to the office of the Vice-Chancellor at meetings held on 28 February, 24 March and 18 April, 1970.

facts.text: The meeting of the Court of the University was convened under notice dated 22 April, 1970 for 9 May, 1970 for election of the Vice-Chancellor from amongst the three persons.

facts.text: At the election held on 9 May, 1970 the total number of votes tendered was 149. One of the votes was invalid. The valid votes were 148.

anchor.surface_text: At the election held on 9 May, 1970 the total number of votes tendered was 149. One of the votes was invalid. The valid votes were 148.

facts.text: First preference votes: Dr. Apte secured 58, Principal Kulkarni 37 and Principal Suru 53.

anchor.surface_text: The result of the ballot papers appeared to be that Dr. Apte secured 58, Principal Kulkarni 37 and Principal Suru 53 first preference votes.

facts.text: Principal Kulkarni was eliminated on the first count on the basis of the lowest number of first preference votes.

anchor.surface_text: Principal Kulkarni was thus eliminated on the first companynt on the basis of the lowest number of first preference votes.

facts.text: 8 of the voters who had given first preference votes to Principal Kulkarni had exercised second preference in favour of either Dr. Apte or Principal Suru. The remaining 29 voters gave 12 second preference votes to Dr. Apte and 17 to Principal Suru.

issues.text: Whether the tie between Dr. Apte and Principal Suru at the second count was to be resolved by drawing of lots as the ordinary practice in elections held under the system of proportional representation by means of a single transferable vote by ballot for election to a single seat

anchor.surface_text: First, it was contended that the tie between Dr. Apte and Principal Suru at the second count was to be resolved by drawing of lots, because it was the ordinary practice in elections held under the system of proportional representation by means of a single transferable vote by ballot for election to a single seat that the tie of the above kind must be resolved by drawing of lots.

issues.text: Whether the Principals of four Colleges which had not been duly affiliated at the date of the election had acted and voted at the election as members of the Court, and therefore the votes given by the members of those four colleges were invalid

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it was said that the Principal of four Colleges, viz. N. D. M. V. P. Samajs Arts and Commerce College, Sinnar V. P. Mandals Arts, Science and Commerce College, Thana Narhar Balwant Thakur Law College, Nasik and E. Societys College for Education, Sangamner which had not been duly affiliated at the date of the election had acted and voted at the election as members of the Court, and, therefore, the votes given by the members of those four colleges were invalid.

issues.text: Whether the meeting for the election of the panel of respondents Dr. Apte, Principal Kulkarni and Principal Suru for election to the office of the Vice-Chancellor was an invalid meeting and therefore the election was void

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, it was contended that the meeting for the election of the panel of respondents Dr. Apte, Principal Kulkarni and Principal Suru for election to the office of the Vice-Chancellor was an invalid meeting and therefore the election was void.

holdings.text: It is an established principle in the system of proportional representation by means of a single transferable vote by ballot that where for one vacancy there are three candidates and one of them is excluded at the first count and the two candidates continued and in the second count both of them have equal number of votes then one of the two candidates who had the lower number of votes than the other continuing candidate in the first count shall be excluded. The present election was held on this principle.

anchor.surface_text: It is an established principle in the system of proportional representation by means of a single transferable vote by ballot that where for one vacancy there are three, candidates and one of them is excluded at the first count and the two candidates continued and in the second count both of them have equal number of votes then one of the two candidates who had the lower number of votes than the other continuing candidate in the first count shall be excluded. The present election was held on this principle.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle recognized in Hare system; analogous application of Rule 75(4), Rule 6 Schedule to Presidential Elections Rules, and Statute 158; legislative recognition.

holdings.text: It cannot be said in the present case that there is any statutory infringement of election by the system of proportional representation by means of a single transferable vote.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be said in the present case that there is any statutory infringement of election by the system of proportional representation by means of a single transferable vote.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Election followed established exclusion principle under section 56 without violation.

holdings.text: Determination by lot in case of equality of votes is neither a principle of universal application nor is it a common law principle. It is only permissible when there is a specific statutory provision to that effect. In the absence of a statutory provision the method of decision by lot is not resorted to when there is other rational method.

anchor.surface_text: Determination by lot in case of equality of votes in neither a principle of universal application nor is it a common law principle. It is only permissible when there is a specific statutory provision to that effect. In the absence of a statutory provision the method of decision by lot is not resorted to when there is other rational method.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lot dependent on chance; rational exclusion by original votes preferred; no specific statutory compulsion here.

holdings.text: The interpretation of rule 75 4 by the High Court is erroneous. The rule itself speaks of two or more candidates and does not speak of more than two candidates as the High Court construed it.

anchor.surface_text: The interpretation of rule 75 4 by the High Court is erroneous. The rule itself speaks of two or more candidates and does not speak of more than two candidates as the High Court construed it. The words stand lowest on the poll occur along with two or more candidates who have been credited with the same value.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading: 'two or more' includes exactly two; resolves tie by original votes.

holdings.text: The principle in rule 81 3 is applicable where more than one seat is to be filled and only one vacancy remains unfilled with only two continuing candidates and each of them has the same value of votes at that count. [...] This is not the case here.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court therefore relied on rule 81 3 of the Conduct of Elections Rules, 1961 to support the conclusion that the only system of exclusion in a case of the present type would be decision by lot. Rule 81 3 is as follows- When at the end of any count only one vacancy remains unfilled and there are only two continuing candidates and each of them has the same value of votes

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 81(3) limited to multi-seat elections with final vacancy; single seat here distinguished.

holdings.text: Delayed publication of the notification would not detract from the sanction previously granted.

anchor.surface_text: Delayed publication of the notification would not detract from the sanction ,previously granted. The third contention which had been urged in the High Court was not pressed here.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Government sanction in June 1969 effective despite delayed publication; evidence shows affiliation for 1969-72.

holdings.text: Even if Statute No. 158 of the Poona University does not in terms apply, Statute No. 158 furnishes a valuable guide regarding the working of the system of proportional representation mentioned in section 56 of the Act and principles analogous to Statute No. 158 are applicable and have been applied by the authorities who conducted the election in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: Even if Statute No. 158 of the Poona University does not in terms apply, Statute No. 158 furnishes a valuable guide regarding the working of the system of proportional representation mentioned in section 56 of the Act and principles analogous to Statute No. 158 are applicable and have been applied by the authorities who conducted the election in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Though not directly applicable to Vice-Chancellor (officer not authority), embodies recognized exclusion rule as guide for s56.

holdings.text: If there are two principles of exclusion and the authority has a discretion in the mode of performing the duty, the authority cannot be commanded to a duty in a specific way.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Authority's rational choice among valid methods immune from mandamus; cited Halsbury.

h1 holds that it is an established principle in proportional representation by single transferable vote that where for one vacancy there are three candidates, addressing the issue i4 of whether the manner of excluding Principal Suru and declaring Dr. Apte elected is a valid principle of exclusion

anchor.surface_text: It is an established principle in the system of proportional representation by means of a single transferable vote by ballot that where for one vacancy there are three, candidates and one of them is excluded at the first count and the two candidates continued and in the second count both of them have equal number of votes then one of the two candidates who had the lower number of votes than the other continuing candidate in the first count shall be excluded. The present election was held on this principle.
For these reasons, we accept the appeal and set aside the judgment of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Determination by lot in case of equality of votes in neither a principle of universal application nor is it a common law principle. It is only permissible when there is a specific statutory provision to that effect. In the absence of a statutory provision the method of decision by lot is not resorted to when there is other rational method.
For these reasons, we accept the appeal and set aside the judgment of the High Court.
